title: Problem Overview
content: Erdős Problem #695: Let p₁ < p₂ < ⋯ be primes with p_{i+1} ≡ 1 (mod p_i). Two questions: (1) Is lim p_k^{1/k} = ∞? (2) Can p_k ≤ exp(k(log k)^{1+o(1)})? Status: OPEN.
mathContext: Posed in [Er79e]. Prime chains connect to cyclic group structure and Linnik's theorem.

title: Prime Chain Definition
content: IsPrimeChain(p) := StrictMono p ∧ (∀i, (p i).Prime) ∧ (∀i, p(i+1) % p i = 1). The sequence is strictly increasing primes with each congruent to 1 mod the previous.
mathContext: Prime chains arise from multiplicative group structure: Z/p_{i+1}Z has subgroup of order p_i.

title: Chain Divisibility
content: ChainDivisibility(p) := ∀i, p_i | (p_{i+1} - 1). Equivalent to p_{i+1} ≡ 1 (mod p_i).
mathContext: The divisibility p_i | (p_{i+1} - 1) is a restatement of the congruence condition.

title: k-th Root Function
content: kthRoot(p, k) = p_k^{1/k}. This measures the 'average exponential rate' of growth up to step k.
mathContext: If p_k grows like c^k, then kthRoot → c. If p_k grows faster than any c^k, then kthRoot → ∞.

title: Question 1: k-th Root to Infinity
content: Question1 := ∀p prime chain, Tendsto(kthRoot p) atTop atTop. Does p_k^{1/k} → ∞ for every prime chain?
mathContext: This asks: does every prime chain grow faster than any exponential c^k?

title: Question 2: Sub-Doubly-Exponential Growth
content: Question2 := ∃p prime chain with p_k ≤ exp(k(log k)^{1+o(1)}). Can we find a slow-growing prime chain?
mathContext: The bound exp(k(log k)^{1+o(1)}) is much slower than exp(exp(Ck)) from the greedy algorithm.

title: Linnik's Theorem
content: ∃L > 0, ∀q prime, ∃p prime with p ≡ 1 (mod q) and p ≤ q^L. Least prime in AP is at most polynomial.
mathContext: Linnik (1944) proved L exists; best known is L ≈ 5 (Xylouris 2011).

title: Greedy Algorithm Bound
content: Greedy (taking smallest prime ≡ 1) gives p_k ≤ exp(exp(O(k))). This is doubly exponential growth.
mathContext: Via Linnik: p_{k+1} ≤ p_k^L, so log p_k ≤ L^k · log p_0, giving doubly exponential.

title: Small Prime Conjecture
content: Conjectured: ∃C, ∀p prime, ∃p' prime with p' ≡ 1 (mod p) and p' ≤ p(log p)^C. If true, Question2 is YES.
mathContext: This conjectured bound would give p_k ≤ exp(k(log k)^{O(1)}), answering Question2 positively.

title: Cunningham Chains
content: IsCunninghamChainFirst(p) := all primes and p_{i+1} = 2p_i + 1. These are special prime chains.
mathContext: Cunningham chains: p, 2p+1, 4p+3, 8p+7,... are prime chains since 2p+1 ≡ 1 (mod p) for odd p.

title: Ford-Konyagin-Luca Analysis
content: FKL (2010) showed various bounds on prime chain lengths and established growth lower bounds.
mathContext: The paper [FKL10] is the most comprehensive study of prime chain growth.

title: Exponential Lower Bound
content: ∃c > 1, ∀p prime chain, ∀k, p_k ≥ c^k. Every prime chain grows at least exponentially.
mathContext: Since p_{i+1} > p_i and p_{i+1} ≡ 1 (mod p_i), we have p_{i+1} ≥ p_i + p_i = 2p_i for large p_i.

title: Problem Status
content: Both Question1 and Question2 are OPEN. The gap between lower bound c^k and upper bound exp(exp(Ck)) is enormous.
mathContext: Neither question has been resolved. The true growth rate of prime chains remains unknown.

title: Main Formal Statement
content: erdos_695_main: For all prime chains p, Tendsto(p_k^{1/k}) atTop atTop ↔ Question1. Formal statement of Part 1.
mathContext: Uses Mathlib's Filter.Tendsto for the limit formulation.

title: Variant Formal Statement
content: erdos_695_variant: Question2 ↔ ∃p chain with p_k ≤ exp(k(log k)^{1+o(1)}). Formal statement of Part 2.
mathContext: Uses Mathlib's Asymptotics for the o(1) notation.
